metadata.case_name: Makhan Singh Tarsikka v. State of Punjab

facts.text: F.I.R. filed at Police Station Jandiala on 22nd October 1962 alleging offences under sections 307, 324, 364 and 367 I.P.C. committed by certain persons including the appellant.
Appellant arrested on 25th October 1962 pursuant to investigation.
Emergency declared by the President on 26th October 1962.
Appellant transferred to judicial custody of Sub-Divisional Magistrate, Amritsar on 1st November 1962.
Appellant allowed to interview nine persons between 3rd November to 19th November 1962 while in jail custody; respondent alleged he instigated them to commit prejudicial activities.
Order of detention passed against appellant on 20th November 1962 under Rule 30(1)(b) of Defence of India Rules 1962; served on 21st November 1962; appellant removed to jail at Hissar.
Appellant brought back to Amritsar on 30th January 1963.
Appellant filed habeas corpus petition on 9th February 1963 challenging detention on grounds of vagueness, concoction and falsity of grounds.
Appellant filed additional affidavit on 4th March 1963 alleging confinement before emergency and Chinese invasion showed allegations false.
Appellant filed third affidavit on 6th March 1963 alleging political activities as MLA disliked by high-ups, starred questions exposing corruption, police enmity due to inquiry ordered by High Court.
Counter-affidavits by respondent disputing appellant's allegations and stating information received about instigation during interviews.
Punjab High Court dismissed habeas corpus petition on 26th March 1963 by judgment and order in Criminal Misc. No. 186 of 1963.
Criminal case against appellant transferred to court in U.P., which allowed bail subject to detention order.

legal_issues.text: Whether service of detention order under Rule 30(1)(b) of Defence of India Rules 1962 is valid when served on person already in jail custody.
Whether detention order can be made against person in jail custody under Rule 30(1)(b).
Whether order passed malafide due to political enmity or other motives.
Whether simultaneous criminal prosecution and preventive detention permissible.

petitioner_arguments.text: Grounds of detention vague, concocted and totally false: indulging in propaganda against joining armed/civil defence forces and contributing to National Defence Fund.
In confinement before declaration of emergency on 26th October 1962 and Chinese invasion, showing allegations false.
Political activities as MLA disliked by high-ups; starred questions exposing corruption; police enraged due to High Court ordered inquiry.
Service of detention order illegal as already in jail custody; relies on Rameshwar Shaw v. District Magistrate Burdwan.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 30(1)(b) Defence of India Rules 1962; Rameshwar Shaw (1964) 4 S.C.R. 918

petitioner_arguments.text: Not open to detain under Rule 30(1)(b) while criminal case under s.307 IPC pending.
Making of detention order invalid as authority knew of jail custody.

respondent_arguments.text: Disputes appellant's allegations in three affidavits.
Appellant instigated persons to prejudicial activities during nine jail interviews from 3rd to 19th November 1962.
Scheme of Rule 30(1) radically different from s.3(1) Preventive Detention Act; wider orders possible; under-trial can send messages via interviews not supervised like detenus.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Rule 30(1) Defence of India Rules 1962; Punjab Detenus Rules 1950 Rules 13,19

court_reasoning.text: Rule 30(1)(b) like s.3(1) Preventive Detention Act postulates person free to act prejudicially if not detained; cannot serve on person in jail custody as no freedom to act prejudicially; follows Rameshwar Shaw.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Service on jail inmate effects double detention, unnecessary and outside purview.

court_reasoning.text: Wider scope of Rule 30(1) does not alter condition for detention under (b): must show freedom to prejudicial activity absent detention.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Could regulate conduct under Rule 30(1)(h) instead.

court_reasoning.text: No need to decide validity of making order or simultaneous prosecution/detention as service invalid; abstractly possible to make order against jail inmate if proximity etc. considered.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Requires material facts; appellant got bail subject to detention.

court_reasoning.text: Mala fides not entertainable: inadequate pleadings, no opportunity to respond; first raised late.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Must be properly pleaded at trial stage.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguishes Emperor v. Mool Chand (mere prior arrest not mala fides); Dayanand Modi (simultaneous detention/prosecution); does not decide Maledath Bharathan.

holdings.text: Service of detention order under Rule 30(1)(b) invalid when appellant already in jail custody.

precedents_cited.case_name: Rameshwar Shaw v. District Magistrate Burdwan
precedents_cited.relevance: Service of detention invalid on jail inmate as no freedom to prejudicial activity.
Prior arrest alone not proof of mala fides.

precedents_cited.case_name: Dayanand Modi v. State of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: No bar on simultaneous detention and prosecution.

precedents_cited.case_name: Maledath Bharathan Malyali v. Commissioner of Police
precedents_cited.relevance: State cannot pursue inconsistent rights of prosecution and detention simultaneously; not decided.

statutes_cited.name: Defence of India Rules, 1962
statutes_cited.relevance: Authorizes detention and other orders to prevent prejudicial activities; service invalid under (b) for jail inmate.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code
statutes_cited.relevance: Offences alleged in FIR leading to arrest.

statutes_cited.name: Preventive Detention Act, 1960
statutes_cited.relevance: Similar to Rule 30(1)(b); construed in Rameshwar Shaw.

statutes_cited.name: Punjab Detenus Rules, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Regulates interviews of detenus in presence of officer.

outcome.summary: Appeal by special leave allowed; order of detention set aside on ground that service on appellant while in jail custody is invalid and outside scope of Rule 30(1)(b) of Defence of India Rules 1962.

key_quotes.text: "If a person is already in jail custody, how can it rationally be postulated that if he is not detained he would act in a prejudicial manner?"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning from Rameshwar Shaw applied to invalidate service.

key_quotes.text: "The service of a detention order on a person who is already in jail custody virtually seeks to effectuate what may be called a double detention and such double detention is not intended either by s.3(1)(a) or by Rule 30(1)(b)".
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Explains why service invalid under the Rule.

key_quotes.text: "A plea of mala fides must always be made by proper pleadings at the trial stage, so that the respondent has an opportunity to meet the said pleadings."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Rejects mala fides plea for lack of proper foundation.
